titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the New Jewish Agenda Records TAM.183
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Peter Filardo, 2011. Addition of Series IV in 2011. 2013 Accession added by Heather Mulliner in October 2013. Edited by Bonnie Gordon to reflect the incorporation of nonprint materials, 2013.

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2014-07-15T15:15-0400

change.item: Edited by Maggie Schreiner to reflect updated administrative information

did.unittitle: New Jewish Agenda Records

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

physdesc.extent: in 41 record cartons, 2 manuscript boxes, and 1 photograph box.

did.langmaterial: Materials are mostly in English, with some items in Hebrew.
did.abstract: New Jewish Agenda (1980-1992), was a progressive multi-issue organization whose members included secular and observant Jews drawn from many sectors of the Left. NJA had some forty-five local chapters and five task forces: Middle East, Economic and Social Justice, Nuclear Disarmament, Central America, and the Feminism (later to include AIDS) task force. NJA also sought to develop a progressive Jewish cultural and religious ethos, reflected in its creation of The Shalom Seders: Three Haggadahs (1984). The process-oriented, “participatory democracy” political culture of NJA complicated its efforts to deal with its infiltration, circa 1987, by the New Alliance Party, whose views were antithetical to those of NJA. The organization also faced hostility from mainstream organized Jewry for its critical view of Israeli foreign policy, ongoing financial difficulties, and the erosion of some of its membership to other, usually single-issue progressive Jewish organizations, and eventually disbanded in 1992. The collection contains national administrative records, including convention, national council and steering council records, including minutes, correspondence, internal bulletins, reports, mailings, membership lists, press releases, some officers’ records (for example, those of Rena Bernards and Anna Jaffe); fundraising, task force and chapter records (including extensive files on the Portland, OR chapter), issues of its national newsletters, Agenda, Agenda-in-Brief and Gesher (published by the Feminist Task Force), photographs, and printed ephemera produced by NJA and other progressive (especially Jewish) organizations.
did.physloc: Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please contact tamiment.wagner@library.nyu.edu at least two business days prior to research visit.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into five series:
Materials in Series I-IV are arranged in the order in which they were received.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material at the Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: New Jewish Agenda (1980-1992), aka “Agenda,” identified itself as “a Jewish voice among progressives and a progressive voice among Jews.” NJA was a multi-issue organization that included secular and observant Jews, Jews from the organized Left (principally the New Left of the 1960s-1970s), and politically unaffiliated Jews; it was organized into some forty-five local chapters. The political concerns of NJA were reflected in the names of the task forces through which the bulk of its activity was conducted: the Middle East Task Force (advocating a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and opposing settlements in the occupied territories), the Economic and Social Justice Task Force, the Nuclear Disarmament Task Force, the Central America Task Force (in particular opposing U.S. policy in El Salvador and Nicaragua), and the Feminism (later to include AIDS) Task Force, which reflected the strong presence of women and homosexuals in Agenda. NJA also sought to develop a progressive Jewish cultural and religious ethos, reflected in its creation of The Shalom Seders: Three Haggadahs (1984), and also devoted some attention to the issues of Soviet Jewry and Ethiopian Jews. The process-oriented, “participatory democracy” political culture of NJA complicated its efforts to deal with its infiltration, circa 1987, by the New Alliance Party, a political cult whose views were antithetical to those of NJA. The organization also faced hostility from mainstream organized Jewry for its critical view of Israeli foreign policy, ongoing financial difficulties, and the erosion of some of its membership to other, usually single-issue progressive Jewish organizations, and eventually disbanded in 1992.

list.head: Sources
list.item: Block, Ethan D. “One Voice Less for the Jewish Left: New Jewish Agenda, 1981-1993.” http://www.newjewishagenda.net/PDFs/onelessvoice.pdf)
Nepon, Emily. “New Jewish Agenda: The History of an Organization, 1980-1992.” Senior thesis, Goddard College, 2006, and related material (http://www.newjewishagenda.net/).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The collection contains national administrative records, including convention, national council and steering council records, including minutes, correspondence, internal bulletins, reports, mailings, membership lists, press releases, some officer’s records ( including those of Rena Bernards and Anna Jaffe); fundraising, task force and chapter records (including extensive files on the Portland, OR chapter), issues of its national periodicals Agenda, Agenda-in-Brief, Internal Discussion Bulletin, Internal Discussion Bulletin on Anti-Semitism, and Gesher (published by the Feminist Task Force), printed ephemera produced by NJA and other progressive (especially Jewish) organizations, photographs, one box of files of Linda Erber,(NJA National Program Coordinator, 1988-1992), and two boxes of Tom Rawson Files (Boston Chapter, miscellaneous national NJA files).

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date; New Jewish Agenda Records; TAM 183; box number; folder number;
Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Elmer Holmes Bobst Library
70 Washington Square South
New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: 36 boxes of records were donated by the New Jewish Agenda in 1995. An additional 5 boxes were incorporated into the collection between 2003 and 2011. The accession numbers associated with these donations are 2003.029, 2003.030 and 2011.001. The Portland, Oregon chapter records were donated in 2006 by Sandy Polishuk and Harry Stein. The Tom Rawson records were donated by Tom Rawson in 2011, the accession number associated with this gift is 2011.069. Most recently, a gift of correspondence relating to membership development was made in 2013. The accession number associated with this donation is 2013.034.

phystech.head: Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Researchers interested in using audiovisual materials in this collection (films, cassette tapes, VHS tapes, et cetera) must use a digitized copy, which we refer to as an access copy. Researchers may view an item’s original container, but the media themselves are not available for playback because of preservation concerns. Materials that already have already been digitized are noted in the collection’s finding aid and can be requested in our reading room; materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. These requests are free of charge and can be made in anticipation of your visit. The process typically takes four to six weeks. To request an access copy be made, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact tamiment.wagner@library.nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A librarian will respond to you with further information.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Copyright (and related rights to publicity and privacy) to materials in this collection created by the New Jewish Agenda are held by the New Jewish Agenda. Permission to publish or reproduce materials to which the organization holds copyright must be secured from the copyright holder. Please contact the Tamiment Library for assistance with contacting the New Jewish Agenda.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Materials from the 2013 accession were incorporated into Series I, Box 7. Photographs were separated from this collection during initial processing and were established as a separate collection, the New Jewish Agenda Photographs (PHOTOS 145). In 2013, the photograph collection was reincorporated into the New Jewish Agenda Records.

did.unittitle: Series I: Records.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Box "TITLES" in quotation marks are from the trans-files in which the records were originally housed.

did.unittitle: National Committee and Steering Committee minutes, meetings and mailings, 1980s
National Committee and Steering Committee minutes, meetings and mailings, beginning 1987
National Committee and Steering Committee minutes, meetings and mailings, 1987-89; three folders from 1982
"NJA 1987-90": Conventions, membership survey 1990; New Alliance Party; other administrative, activities, and topical files.
"NJA 1987-90" - National Committee and Steering Committee minutes, strategic direction meetings; Chapter Files, Providence, RI - Z, and Canada
Miscellaneous: much loose material, and unlabelled files
"File cabinet drawers 1-2, 1981-82": Council meetings, correspondence, membership development, "Conference" [possibly] founding conference; topical files

"File cabinet drawers 1-2, 1981-82" conclusion: includes Steering Committee 1982-83; Internal Discussion Bulletin on Anti-Semitism, “Awareness and Action, A Resource Book on Anti-Semitism,” "NJA 1985-86" [11"]: mailings, workshops, funding proposals, 1985 convention

"NJA 1985-86" conclusion [11"]: National Committee correspondence, fundraising, task forces [Middle East, economic justice], 1985 convention; "Staff files, pre 1991": foundations [mostly reference material, forms, and some correspondence], contributions, thank you letters
"Pre 1991 staff files": foundations [mostly reference material, forms, and some correspondence], contributions, thank you letters
"Pre 1991 staff files" [9"] - foundations, chapter handbook; "NJA 1980" [6"] - topical and administrative files [1980s]
"NJA 1980": Founding convention, December, 1980; Early newsletters; "Annette Jaffe's files" [11"]: Steering Committee, Task Forces, packets for events
Financial; Serials [Newsletter, Agenda, Agenda-in-Brief] Conference and convention bulletins and brochures, including some draft versions and associated reference material
Serials, conclusion; "NJA 1983-84": begins with "Direct mail proposal" folder, also includes elections, financial, G2 merger, fundraising
"NJA 1983-84 conclusion”; Middle East Task Force, Central America; General correspondence, National Committee, Development, Fat file of chapter flyers, newsletters, etc., 1989
Miscellaneous staff files, 1989-90 [11"]; National Committee meetings, mailings, minutes; National convention; New Alliance Party

Miscellaneous office files, including chapter activity handbook, Shalom Seders, Bay Area Arbitration, 1984 [Bay Area Chapter charter revoked for advocating aid cutoff to Israel, while national NJA policy was neutrality on this issue]

Miscellaneous office files; "Miscellaneous staff files, 1980s": including the Advisory Board, 1988 report, “General Support Proposal,” 1989; Middle East Task Force, Thank you letters, A-K; Large donors
Thank you letters, L-Z, General Support Proposal, other files [11"]; Middle East files, including 1983 Israel tour
Membership, circa 1988, by Chapter
Middle East files: tours, 1986-87, settlement freeze, 1987 World Zionist Congress, Americans for a Progressive Israel; Middle East Task Force
Middle East Task Force: mailings, press releases, Internal Discussion Bulletin, 1987-90; Some 1991 documents
Middle East: Gulf War 1991; Middle East Task Force 1982 - 1989
Middle East / Middle East Task Force, circa 1983-88, including Middle East Task Force internal documents, 1983-84; Shalom network
Chapter files - Akron – L
Chapter files [9"]: M - Portland, OR; Holiday services by NJA and others
Press Clips [mentioning NJA]
Central America Task Force

Central America Task Force [10"]: correspondence, Nicaragua, sanctuary; Steering Committee; “NJA History" [begins with "Lease" file]; Miscellaneous administrative, activities, and topical files, circa 1984-88

"NJA History" [10"]: "E" alphabetical file, including NJA elections, Economic justice, El Salvador; Miscellaneous 1985 files; “Rena Bernards’ files," [begins with "negative mail" folder, and includes "Platform," 1982]

"Miscellaneous 1985 [Rena] Bernards’ files": alphabetical by keyword, M – Z: contains administrative, activities, and topical files, including National Committee, Nairobi, nuclear weapons, and volunteers
Middle East, A - N [roughly alphabetical by keyword]: administrative, activities, and topical files
Middle East [8"] N - Z [alphabetical by keyword]; Disarmament / Soviet Jewry / Economic and Social Justice Task Force, [most material is ESJTF and Disarmament, little on Soviet Jewry]
"Disarmament /Soviet Jewry / Economic and Social Justice Task Force," conclusion [11"]: mostly peace activity, ESJTF; Gesher [Feminist task force newsletter of NJA], Jewish Socialist
Jewish Organizations, mostly progressive: printed ephemera and/or correspondence with NJA [box is half full]
Middle East activities and Task Force, Internal Discussion Bulletin
Series II: Portland, Oregon Chapter Records.

Portland Chapter: about half of box consists of envelopes addressed to Harry Stein; the box contains a “NJA History” envelope, chapter and national newsletters (Agenda), ephemera, including from other progressive organizations, and some correspondence

Portland Chapter: about half of box consists of envelopes addressed to Harry Stein; the box contains chapter and national newsletters (Agenda), ephemera, including from other progressive organizations, and some correspondence
Series III: Linda Erber Files
Linda Erber Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Contents description provided by Linda Erber (NJA National Program Coordinator, 1988-1992) follows:
Carrying It On: National Conference Organizing Against Anti-Semitism and Racism (November 8-10, 1991, Philadelphia):

Proceedings; Xerozes of speeches; Transcripts of taped speeches; Organizing papers including letters to panelists, workshop leaders permission forms, confirmation agreements (including Julian Bond and Grace Paley), panelist biographies; Various organizing papers, training packet; Conference booklet. Awareness and Action: A Resource Book on Anti-Semitism, 1991
Draft Manual for Organizing National Conferences
Notebook with various task force organizing notes (1988)
Jewish Womens' Committee To End The Occupation file (JWCEO)
Misc. organizing papers, pamphlets, bulletins, correspondence and notes

did.unittitle: Audio and Videocassettes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: "Carrying It On" NJA conference, audiocassettes, 1991; Ron Young, speech, videoccassette.

did.unittitle: Series IV: Tom Rawson Files
Boston New Jewish Agenda Chapter Records plus Miscellaneous National NJA Records (Includes Middle East Task Force)
National New Jewish Agenda Records, Miscellaneous
Series V: Photographs

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Many of the negatives have either matching prints or contact sheets. Those prints or contact sheets and the negatives that matched them have been separated, but placed in folders that have labels that state that they have either prints/contacts or negatives which match.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series includes 241 black and white photographs, 52 color photographs, 6 photocopies, 43 contact sheets, 3 strips of 110 film, a 2 1/4" negative, about 41 rolls of 35mm negatives, 5 4x5 negatives, a copy of the minutes from a meeting of the Steering Committee, an invitation to "The Arab and the Israeli," hate mail, and 15 graphics for an unspecified publication.
